awd_titl_txt: Child Trends News Service: Advancing Social Science Knowledge to Benefit Hispanic Families - Phase 2
awd_abstract_narration:
As part of its overall strategy to enhance learning in informal environments, the Advancing Informal STEM Learning (AISL) program funds innovative research, approaches, and resources for use in a variety of settings.  In this Innovations and Development project, Child Trends, in collaboration with Ivanhoe Broadcast News, will expand the reach of the Child Trends News Service, and rigorously evaluate its impact on viewers.  The News Service aims to build the public's knowledge of, and appreciation for, social science research and to encourage adoption of research-informed parenting practices associated with positive child development--particularly among Latino parents. First produced in 2017 through a NSF proof of concept grant, the Child Trends News Service covers actionable, child-focused, social science research.  By featuring this research on local TV news, the project expands access to evidence-based parenting recommendations.  As of February 2018, 89 stations had subscribed to the News Service, including eight stations in the top 25 Latino-serving TV markets that reach 38% of all Hispanic TV Households in those 25 markets.  This project is a response to the challenges faced by U.S. children, of whom more than one in five live in poverty.  The focus on Latino parents is in response Latinos' increasing share of all children, and that Latino children are disproportionately poor, in comparison to their peers.  The project will examine the impact of the News Service on parents who view the news reports in their homes, as well as Latino parents viewing the News Service as part of their participation in the Abriendo Puertas (Opening Doors) community-based parenting program.  This research will contribute to the knowledge base of what we know about how people access and use science, technology, engineering and math (STEM) information across settings. 

The overarching aim of this project is to leverage commercial television news to reach populations who have historically been underrepresented in STEM education and careers. The goals of the project are to:
1.	Build and manage an interdisciplinary collaborative, including news media professionals, researchers, practitioners in organizations serving at-risk families, and experts in STEM communications and Latino studies.
2.	Leverage mass media news outlets to deliver social science research on children to at-risk populations, with a focus on reaching Latino parents.
3.	Advance the field of informal STEM learning by exploring how the public interacts with actionable research on child development to inform their knowledge, attitudes and behaviors.
4.	Expand the reach and application of the news products through strategic outreach to other stakeholders in the child development field including programs serving under-served families.
To accomplish these goals, the project will further strengthen an Advisory Panel to inform content development, study design, interpretation of findings, dissemination of study results, and the transition of the project after the NSF grant period.  The project will continue to provide eight (both in English and Spanish) stories each month to TV stations and strategically grow the reach in top Latino markets.  The editorial process will be informed by surveys of Latino parents to identify topics of interest.  Through a random-assignment impact study with local TV news audiences from diverse racial/ethnic groups, the project will evaluate the impact of the News Service.  The project will use formative research methods to refine messaging and examine the potential for repurposing the videos through a parenting program for Latino parents.

The Child Trends News Service seeks broader impacts in three areas: increasing the public's scientific literacy and engagement with science and technology; increasing partnerships between academia, industry, and others; and improving the well-being of individuals in society.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

FINAL OUTCOMES REPORT 

          The Child Trends News Service: Advancing Social Science Knowledge to Benefit Hispanic Families Phase-2, an Innovations and Development grant 

Broader Impacts: The Child Trends News Service (CTNS) project's overarching goal is to build awareness of and appreciation for social science research and to promote the adoption of research-informed parenting practices associated with positive outcomes for children. The project is focused on reaching scientifically underserved sectors of the country, particularly Latino and low-income parents, through their preferred information source--local TV news.i Research finds that 46 percent of adults who earn less than $30,000 and 84 percent who have at most a high school degree regularly watch local TV news.i This is a particularly important audience given that greater value and knowledge of STEM research is linked to higher levels of education.ii Since the project's inception, Child Trends has collaborated with a leading professional news syndicator, Ivanhoe Broadcast News, to produce monthly news reports in both English and Spanish. The project's newsfeed, Positive Parenting, aired in 118 of the 210 U.S. TV markets, including 16 of the top 25 Latino-serving markets, and each report amassed an average of 71 million views. The CTNS project bridges across researchers, news professionals, and parents to advance the knowledge base of the field of informal STEM learning and communications.

 

In addition, Latino children are the largest and fastest-growing minority group of children; yet they are disproportionately poor and lag their peers on a range of indicators.iii As Latinos become an increasing share of the nation's child population, the future workforce of the country is increasingly linked to how Latino children develop and thrive. Broadening Latino parents' access to and engagement with child development research linked to positive child outcomes is central to the project's mission. To this end, Child Trends worked closely with Abriendo Puertas/Opening Doors (AP/OD) to conduct extensive audience research with Latino parents, including surveys and focus groups, to inform the development of culturally relevant news messages and to adapt the news videos for their parenting program--the largest parenting program for low-income Latinos in the country.

 

Intellectual Merit: Building off a previous NSF-funded project, Discoveries and Breakthroughs Inside Science, Child Trends conducted an experimental study among 396 local TV news watchers to assess the impact of the news reports on parents' knowledge, value for science, and behavior changes. The impact study was the first to successfully link exposure to commercial news reports on scientific research to viewers' intent to adopt and adoption of science-based behaviors. The study also found that parents in the treatment group were significantly more likely to have knowledge of the featured science content and express value for the sciences. Published results of the RCT are forthcoming in Psychology, Public Policy, and Lawiv and under review in the Journal of Children and Media. Specifically, parents in the treatment group were significantly more likely to indicate: 

  • Positive perceptions about the utility of the social sciences, specifically agreeing that researchers care about the same things they care about and that social scientists in general are working to improve people's lives.
  • A higher likelihood of believing that scientific research on parenting is useful on topics such as children and discipline and the use of electronic devices.
  • Support for policies funding scientific research. 
  • Knowledge about topics covered in the news reports in seven out of nine questions, such as knowing that playing with blocks can help children develop math skills. 
  • Intent to adopt behaviors featured in the videos, such as praising children's effort instead of achievement. 
  • Adoption of some of the featured behaviors described in the videos one week and one month after watching the news report, such as exposing children to foreign languages, among others. 

The results of this study suggest that the collaborative partnership between child development researchers and TV news media advances learning that leads to adoption of science-based parenting behaviors, and that this model may have implications for other fields of science. Reaching parents on a large scale with vetted research on critical parenting topics, such as child development, climate change, and child mental health--through a medium they trust and access frequently--can serve as a model for initiatives that seek to have wider impact.

[i] Pew Research Center. (2019). Local TV News Fact Sheet. https://www.journalism.org/fact-sheet/local-tv-news/

[ii] NSF Science and Engineering Indicators, 2018.

[iii] Murphey, D., Guzman, L., & Torres, A. (2014). America’s Hispanic Children: Gaining Ground, Looking Forward. Bethesda, MD: Child Trends. https://www.childtrends.org/wp-content/uploads/2014/09/2014-38AmericaHispanicChildren.pdf

[iv] Torres, A., Piña, G., Southwell, B., & Garcia-Baza, I. (forthcoming). Can Local TV News Affect Parents’ Perceptions of Parenting and Child Development Research? Evidence from the Positive Parenting Newsfeed Project. Psychology, Public Policy, and Law.
